title: Ellen DeGeneres defends friendship with George W Bush amid backlash
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Talk show host Ellen DeGeneres has defended her friendship with former president George W Bush after she faced backlash.

The star was seen laughing with the republican politician at an NFL game over the weekend, with social media going hard on the 61-year-old.

Not taking the hate at all, the star addressed the situation this week.

Speaking on her show on Monday, she insisted she was invited to the game by the daughter of the Dallas Cowboys owner, Charlotte Jones, who also invited many other famous faces including Ellen’s wife Portia de Rossi.

Advertisement

And George Dubya.

‘When we were invited, I was aware that we were going to be surrounded by many other people from different views and beliefs,’ she said, showing a video she took of the star-studded box.

Ellen was seen alongside George (Picture: FOX)

‘And I’m not talking about politics… I was rooting for the [Green Bay] Packers. So I had to hide my cheese hat in Portia’s purse.

‘During the game they showed a shot of George and me laughing together and people were upset. They thought, “Why is a gay Hollywood liberal sitting next to a conservative Republican president?”’

She continued, addressing the backlash: ‘Here’s the thing. I’m friends with George Bush. I’m friends with a lot of people who don’t share the same beliefs that I have. We’re all different and I think we’ve forgotten that that’s okay that we’re all different…

‘Just because I don’t agree with someone on everything doesn’t mean I’m not going to be friends with them. When I say, “Be kind to one another,” I don’t only mean only the people who think the same way that you do. I mean be kind to everyone.

‘It doesn’t matter.’

Ellen joked: ‘Even people who are already playing Christmas music, seriously, there is no excuse for that. But I’m kind to them.’

In a sign that all is not horrible, the comedian shared a tweet that had been sent amid the maelstrom that read: ‘Ellen and George Bush together makes me have faith in America again.’

Let’s all live life like that tweeter, eh?
